Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Liquid-Based Intelligent High-Frequency Components

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
High-frequency electronic components play an important role in our daily lives. They cover the broad frequency range from radio frequency (RF) to microwave to terahertz (THz). Typical applications include wireless fidelity (Wi-Fi) systems, microwave ovens, bluetooth systems, wireless power transfer, satellite communication, anti-collision car radar, airport security check systems, THz imaging, and many others. With the advent of these systems, high-frequency electronic components are now required to support electronic systems operating in many different frequency bands and with different characteristics. To address this issue, it is important to design and realize high-frequency electronic components with reconfigurable and highly flexible responses (e.g. THz components with tunable frequency band and large modulation depth). Up to now, almost all of such high-frequency components are made of solid materials. Their physical structures are rigid, fixed and difficult to reconfigure. This research will study novel liquid-based high-frequency electronic components. The employment of liquids to replace conventional solid materials will facilitate the generation of reconfigurable and intelligent electronic systems with high adaptability. The intelligence is enabled by electronically manipulating liquid movements and morphing its shape. The proposed research will pave the way for the development of liquid-based electronic systems. In addition to advancing knowledge in both science and engineering, the proposed project will have potential broad impacts to our society, including improvements to communication, safety, health care, and defense systems. This project will also produce exciting learning and training opportunities for students.

The explosive development of communication systems in the past decade has imposed stringent design challenges for high-frequency components. For example, the emerging THz technology has called for the innovative design of THz components with advanced functionalities. The proposed project aims to realize efficient use and control of liquid materials to adaptively change the responses of high-frequency devices, from which system level intelligence can be achieved to actively control these devices for optimal performance. Electrowetting on dielectric (EWOD) will be employed as the tuning mechanism to realize agile actuation and programmable transport of liquids. The resulting novel liquid-based high-frequency devices can operate efficiently at the broad spectrum from RF/microwave to THz. By leveraging multi-disciplinary knowledge in electromagnetics and electrowetting techniques, this project has the following three innovations: (1) design of novel liquid-based THz components with transformative characteristics and properties; (2) use of the EWOD technique to realize adaptive tuning of the high-frequency devices with reconfigurable and programmable responses; (3) tuning of high-frequency components through three-dimensional manipulation of liquids. The proposed research represents a systematic and interdisciplinary effort to realize liquid-based high-frequency components with a fully electronically-controlled tuning and flexible properties, covering a broad range of applications such as communications, security, and sensing. The proposed design will be verified by experimental results and module demonstration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the advent of high frequency electronic systems, adaptive and reconfigurable structures of the electronic devices are indispensable to support electronic systems operating in many different frequency bands and with different characteristics. However, almost all of such high frequency components are currently made of solid materials whose structures are fixed, rigid and difficult to be reconfigurable. In this project, we have developed and demonstrated a novel liquid-based tuning system which can adaptively reflect high frequency signals to different directions and receivers. The system comprises a steering mechanism based on the electrowetting-on-dielectric (EWOD) with an open-plate configuration. Via three-dimensional printing technique, a nanolattice structure with light weight and ultrahigh strength is fabricated as the rotation hub in the steering system, and an enhanced optical reflector film is used as the signal reflector. The EWOD platform is fabricated by sequentially depositing patterned Au rotary electrodes, Ta2O5 dielectric layer and fluoropolymer hydrophobic layer on a glass substrate. An AC voltage is applied to transport a water or ionic liquid droplet along the annular electrode path to activate and rotate the specular reflector. An electro- mechanical model of resistance-capacitance (RC) circuit network is also developed to analyze the electrowetting driving force. Our theoretical analysismodel shows that the electrowetting driving force has a peak value in the order of 100 μN and the peak value position changes with the AC frequency; the experimental results demonstrate the film reflector can be tuned with an omnidirectional orientation of 360° by our rotary EWOD device and the droplet moving speed can reach as high as ~6.5 mm/s.

We have designed and fabricated EWOD-controlled liquid prisms for adaptive and agile steering of electromagnetic signals. The liquid prism module is a square cuvette with glass sidewalls coated with thin electrodes of indium tin oxide (ITO). The electrode layer is then covered by a thin dielectric insulator (parylene C or Si3N4). Two immiscible fluids, water and silicone oil, are added to the module and voltages are applied to the sidewall electrodes to modulate the fluid-fluid interface. To increase the conductivity of the water, 1wt% of KCl is added to water. To decrease surface tension between the water and the oil, 1wt% of SDS (asurfactant) is added for lowering the driving voltages to tens of volts. To characterize the performance of thus-fabricated electrowetting devices and liquid-based components, we have used custom-designed control system to test the dynamic tunability of these devices. We have also conducted experiment at the visible frequency band to verify the performance of such liquid-based platforms for dynamically manipulating light propagation. Importantly, we have sucessfully demonstrated a functioning dual liquid prism module with enhanced steering performance compared to single prism module.

This project has partially supported two graduate students and one high school student as summer intern. The research results generated by this project have been integrated into the PIs’ undergraduate-level and graduate-level courses (e.g. Microfluidics and Nanofluidics). Based on the project results, we have published over 3 journal and conference papers. At least four manuscripts are in preparation and will be submitted to journals. The research experience gained through this project has inspired us to explore more in the area of tunable electromagnetic devices and systems and make more profound impact to our society.
